commentBody: A little too quick for a Friday.  I liked a bunch of the answers but they were easy to fill in.
Very sweet, very fast. Fine Robyn Weintraub Friday answers (as is her wont), but with Tuesday/Wednesday clues.
Almost 9 minutes faster than my Friday average. Meh. Prefer more of a challenge on Fri.
I done did this puzz....

We haven‚Äôt seen Robyn Weintraub in the NYT for almost nine months, although she‚Äôs been in the New Yorker a few times. Although Robyn has ‚Äúhit for the cycle,‚Äù by far her most common day of publication has been Friday. And this one was a very smooth Friday offering.
Fast but fun, all good. I especially liked the 'doesn't take the regular train home' clue

Whizzing through this thoroughly delightful Robyn Weintraub Friday puzzle brought back impressionistic memories of Robyn Weintraub Fridays of Yore, bathing me in warm nostalgia.

(Also hit my fastest Friday solve ever.)
Missed it by üëåüèªthat much‚Ä¶.
Fine but faster than I was hoping for.  But a high quality puzzle!

I found this to be a bit tougher than some Robyn Weintraub Fridays, but as I was doing the puzzle, I was impressed by how her cluing lets you zero in on the right answer extremely quickly, even for longer and unhackneyed entries like GHOST STORIES and ALL STAR CAST for me.  Getting to those answers in less adept hands might have been a struggle, but not with Robyn as the constructor.  What others call "too easy," I would describe as a tribute to Robyn's skill.
Early birds as usual going on about how easy the Friday puzzle was and how they whizzed right through it. Well, give a thought for us mere mortals who found it both fun and challenging!

Immaculate.  This is why she has the reputation she does.  I found it pretty speedy and the early XWStats rating is Average, which seems about right.  (As a Friday I'd probably vote Easy.)

But there's no junk fill and some interesting clues throughout.  Reading the column, I think the constructor achieved her aims here.

A pleasure.  Welcome back.

I found this one a little less easy than the rest of the early birds, perhaps because I was savoring the substantial number of delightful entries, particularly the long downs. CHECKPLEASE was particularly pleasing, as was TMINUSZERO.  It took me longer than it should have to come up with FACEREALITY and REMAINCALM.  A fun Friday, and like baby bear‚Äôs porridge, just right for me.

Crossword constructor Paolo Pasco emerged with a hard fought win on Jeopardy tonight to secure a place in the Tournament of Champions final round.   It was a tight two person contest heading into final Jeopardy with Pasco holding a slim lead. The final question was very tough and none of the three got it correctly, but Pasco prevailed by making the unconventional bet (for the person in the lead) of $0, relying on his competitor to get the final question wrong, and defying the more common strategy of betting enough to ensure that if you get it right, none of your opponents can get it right even if they bet everything.  Perhaps in addition to being a crackerjack constructor, he‚Äôs also psychic.

This was so good! I am getting better at Friday puzzles. Thank you,  Robyn. Another stellar job. Y‚Äôall have a great Friday, and if you live in the Eastern US stay safe & warm. We may actually get snow instead of ice this weekend in the NC mountains. Yay! ‚òÉÔ∏èüå®Ô∏è‚ùÑÔ∏èü•∂

Aw, a Robyn Weintraub puzzle‚Ä¶ Now that‚Äôs always a treat. Put a smile on my face.  

Not as fast as everyone else today. You know what else starts with a D, has 4 letters, and fits ‚ÄúWhoa ... that's too much for my brain 
to handle?‚Äù DErP. Filled that in without a second thought. And for FACE REALITY, I insisted on boom!REALITY for a touch too long. 

Sometimes the initial wrong guesses are as fun as the right ones. 

Back to the regular scheduled programming, which is to sleep, perchance to dream. (Hopefully not about BABY GROOTs. Good grief how I wish I hadn‚Äôt googled that in the middle of the night.)

Happy Friday, y‚Äôall.

Absence makes the heart grow fonder? 

But I already loved Robyn Weintraub Fridays
Thanks Robyn for letting me know about Bristol Basin.
These days it‚Äôs a big ask to REMAIN CALM if you FACE REALITY.
Favorite crossword of the year so far.

20A PIN broke open the nw corner for me, which had stumped me for a while.  That answer and type of clue have managed to finally to stick in my memory.  

I echo all the nice comments below.  Pleasant misdirect at 46D where bRos persisted for a while, until it didn‚Äôt.

Nice and simple 14 minute solve. Only thing that tripped me up was the SE. Had cHiS crossing with ORTHi and TAc. But Sparta starts with Sigma, Crete with Kappa, so I tried again with ORTHO. Only Greek letter ending with ho is RHO, so TAR worked

GOES BONKERS?
GOES BANANAS?
GOES BELLY UP?

GOES BERSERK!

There are so many ways to go.

Engaging puzzle.  Didn't notice it was a Weintraub production until I came to the comments.

Another day of *almost* having my heinie handed to me.  I don't know how I came up with a T at the crossing of BABYGROOT/STAX, because I didn't recognize either answer, not even a little bit.  But there is where I got the unexpected happy music.  

Never heard of MEWS, not sure why TATA is British, luv, never heard of PLEBE week, never thought of Eggshell as a SHEEN, I pay no attention to car logos, so ACURA was a surprise, TMINUSZERO doesn't sound very NASAy to me, and I've never had the bubbly chocolate concoction known as AERO.

I don't know anything about Florida cities like SOUTH BEACH other than I never want to be in any of them (humidity hater, cold, crisp air lover).  Never heard of SOUTH BEACH other than that's where LeBron took his talents to, at one point.

It's been a long time since I've heard anybody RADIO ahead, but maybe that's because I stopped watching cop shows a long time ago.

But, all on me.  All on me.

So, other than those 10 or 15 problems, I found it very straightforward and easy, just like everyone else here.

Only Robyn Weintraub would fret over a ‚Äúweak‚Äù entry like BALLASTS. We missed you!
You had me at BABY GROOT and then you had me at CHECKPLEASE.
I didn‚Äôt think was too easy, just about perfect (as always for Robyn). Actually a bit challenging  for me with a lot of misdirects and wrong initial guesses.
If I could spell BERSERK I would have had that first but since I can‚Äôt I had GOESBONKERS. Then there was SOUTHMIAMI before SOUTHBEACH and TAXFORM for ‚Äúenter here‚Äù before TEXTBAR, NOTES before TONES, STOOD and GOTUP before SATUP, TAUS before RHOS, GRIN before BEAM, PLUS before PERK‚Äîso I was jumping all over the place. Just how I like it!
In the end a slew of fun fresh entries and clues. And it all culminated in the perfect STAY CALM and FACE REALITY (which are not always compatible). Thanks for a great puzzle, Robyn.

Yes @Robyn Weintraub I love your puzzles!
Fun entries - some puzzled me a good bit, but the crossings and passage of time saved me, so no lookups.  I think you and editors could go with more of the fun tricky clues for a Friday, like "stopped lying", " enter here".
Glad my mom knew what BITUMEN was cause I sure didn‚Äôt!

I'm laying down the red carpet and throwing an euro-disco dance party to welcome back Robyn Weintraub! https://youtu.be/wC_kCnm3GYQ?si=O72q5pbaf2dLhBtO It's been too long since we've been regaled with Robyn's artistry, craftsmanship and creativity ‚Äì the elegant misdirects that trick just enough to challenge but without frustration; the resistance that's just the right dose without being impenetrable. Always a beautiful puzzle, always a delightful romp. Thank you so much, Robyn. You're a luminous crossword star!

Right off the bat I have to ask...

1A...isn't ARTS kind of a broad answer for two very specific art forms in the clue?  I get it, it's Friday, but it's hard for me to know how anyone could have confidently enter ARTS given the clue.  

Maybe there's more I need to learn about crosswords?

This is why I find puzzles like this difficult--there are just so many ways an answer can go.  

Another example, 9A [Stopped lying].  AROSE, STOOD?  No, SAT UP.  Not really the kind of lying I wish so dearly would stop, but I guess we take what we can get.

And of course the oft mentioned below GOESBERSERK, or GOESBELLYUP, or GOESBONKERS.  

I found footing quite hard to come by.  I guess that's what makes it a good puzzle?

Hey Sam, know what else fits 9A? "Stood". 

It lasted far longer than it probably should have, but eventually, with none of the crossings working in that corner, I stood down stood, and finally got the NW done. 

Fun puzzle. Fast, yes, but fun.
Clever and fun.  One of those where I was on the right wavelength for whatever reason but I can see how it would otherwise have been difficult.

Slightly tougher than the typical Robyn Weintraub puzzle but a joy nonetheless.

Can someone please explain how 'Every Day, Say' translate to ALOT? Been racking my brains over this one.
Great puzzle. As always, you are wonderful, Robyn.

Just the right challenge to usher in the weekend.
Thanks

userLocation: no longer writing like E. E. Cummings
commentBody:
Even had I not seen her name before starting, by the end of, say, ten or fifteen clues and fills I'd have known it was a Weintraub.

She is my favorite drug dealer.

Her clueing is never too stepped on or overwhelming, reliably gets me just where I need to go, has very few if any negative side effects and always leaves me a little slumped over, dopily smiling, drooling a bit, breathing shallowly and wondering when my next fix will come.

Not a PB but well below my Friday average.  Didn't have much entered after the first pass.  Gradually the dominoes fell.  Far SE corner gave me a scare, I had the rest of the puzzle completed and still had exactly zilch in that little area.  Started with an S in the lowest far right space, guessed BOX to complete TEXTBOX, guessed BEACH to complete SOUTHBEACH, then with that toehold the rest filled in quickly.  Enjoyable puzzle!
Any puzzle that features BABY GROOT gets my seal of approval <3
Help! Why does ‚ÄúEggshell‚Äù solve to ‚ÄúSHEEN‚Äù? I‚Äôm lost‚Ä¶

Robyn is back!!! Fun-filled Friday grid that was a pleasure to solve. I fell victim to several of the same misdirects as others, but the crosses easily took care of them. 

Thank you and welcome back, Robyn. You‚Äôve been missed ü•∞

Sometimes there's a fill that I'd rather unsee.  BABYGROOT is one of those.

I don't know Babygroot (one word?  should it be two?), and I'd rather not become acquainted with BABYGROOT.

A comment on T-MINUS ZERO; it really isn't used that much these days‚Äîthe launch folks just count down to one and then say "ignition" and "lift-off", but it's still an accurate phrase.

When the weather is clear, I can walk to the back of my apartment building and watch the flame from rockets launched at Cape Canaveral ascending over the Margaritaville Orlando Resort, which I did last night and which I could do again if I wanted to stay up another hour and go outside in our 44¬∞F Florida weather. I'm a bit over 60 miles WSW from the launch site, but still get a fairly good view.

For anyone that's interested, there are phone apps that alert you to launches, and many are shown on YouTube, so can be watched from anywhere there's reception. Learned from experience that there's about a 10-second delay with the video feed.

More trivia: when they were assigning overlay area codes, they were thinking about assigning this one to Chicago, but people insisted that the 3-2-1 code be assigned to the Cape Canaveral area for obvious reasons, and it was.

A fine Friday! I haven‚Äôt seen it commended here yet, so I‚Äôll shoutout the symmetric pairing of 24A‚Äôs LAT and 42A‚Äôs LON! 

SPIRALGALAXY and BABYGROOT also excellent. Elegant puzzle.

I always struggle with Robyn Weintraub puzzles. She has a knack for using words in their less common meanings, which must be why seasoned American solvers love her grids. However, for a non-native speaker the challenge is less enjoyable. Don't get me wrong, I like and appreciate misdirection, but the more levels it comes on, the harder it is for me to deal with it. Still, I almost managed to solve the puzzle unaided. It took longer than a full Saturday solve, but in 40 minutes I filled almost the whole grid. A single mistake in the still largely empty NE corner was my downfall. I had entered STOOD for "Stopped lying" (that was a nice clue btw!), and chaos ensued. The O of STOOD led to my (tentatively) entering OTIS for the transportation company - lifts are a form of transport in rhe wider sense, aren't they? It seemed a Weintraubian-enough answer to me. The T of STOOD in turn had me enter (TOP)STARCAST. There was just no way out of this mess I had created by erring. I knew I had made a mistake, but where? Of course I had no idea what the Annapolis clue was referencing, so I looked it up in desperation. PLEBE... That was enough for me to catch all my mistakes. A Robyn Weintraub Friday solved with one lookup? As a Polish guy I'll consider that a win. And here's Lucek the Poodle exploring a tangle of blackthorn bushes: https://imgur.com/a/zckYI8G
Had to take some wild swings but my guessing really paid off. Tough, but I think, very fair and ultimately satisfying puzzle.
BABYGROOT crossing STAX is not fair.
I‚Äôm clear on why BABY GROOT is new to me, but how well-known or obscure is ‚ÄúElvis at Stax‚Äù?
If it feels like a Robyn Weintraub, it is a Robyn Weintraub... Thank you once again for a smooth, full of "aha!" moments and thoroughly enjoyable puzzle, Robyn!

There are some puzzles, this one most definitely, when I think the constructor constructs sets of several words of a given length:  a set of three letter words, a set of letter words, etc.

Then for each set this demonic constructor will construct two or three *that can be clued the same way*.  

I mean, how else can you explain 9A [Stopped lying]?  After I saw SHUTUP wouldn't fit, (makes sense in my dark world), I thought aha, AROSE!  No, STOOD...much later SATUP.

Just a masterpiece of ambiguity.  Lots of fun.
Seems I always find room for a CHEESEBOARD when I should really be asking for the CHECKPLEASE!
Happy Weintraub day everybody!
Just right for a Friday. Thanks Robyn!

Before I made it from GOB‚Ä¶ to GOBERSERK I spent some time feeling üçåü§™ as well asü¶áüí©ü§™. 

Gotta love how many euphemisms for going insane we have in English. üôÉ

Great puzzle!

No -  MEWS does not usually refer to row houses! A mews consists of small city houses in an alley behind large mansions, which were used in the 18th and 19th centuries for horse stables with servants living above.  
Mews are sometimes accessed through a high archway, originally tall enough for a coach and horses. Often with a cobbled road - picturesque - and although small, with no garden (or yard) usually very, very expensive because of their location. 

A row house is usually called a terraced house, or may be on a crescent, it the street is that shape.

I always enjoy Robyn's puzzles and usually speed through them, but this was pleasantly more challenging than I was expecting. It didn't help that A LIST ACTORS has same letter count (and much overlap) with ALL STAR CAST.

The lower left and center were the last sections for me to complete. By that time, it was 2am it seemed that 58 across was written especially for me. ("Whoa...that's too much for my brain to handle.") I really overthought those sections and it drove me cray-cray. The most frustrating clue was "British rowhouses". I kept coming back to "terraced houses" and nothing else would come to the surface of my poor brain. For all the frustration and time wasted, I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle. I would love to see more from this constructor.

I had some trouble with 46D. I deduced that Alpha most likely refers to the generation, but was stuck trying to find a 4- letter word for a little league team or a boy scout troop... I had to get quite a few crossing letters until I realised that the oldest Gen Alpha are already in college and joining FRATs

This was a weird one for me. Like yesterday, I was somehow half done in 3(!) minutes, mostly on the top half‚Ä¶but then ran right into a wall when all the right ideas stopped occurring to me. Eventually got through in a slower-than-average time. Very nice puzzle though.

A fine puzzle and came in at a new Friday best at a little over eight minutes.  Just vibed with the clues today.  

Felt like Forrest Gump playing ping pong.  

As Old Lodge Skins says at the end of Little Big Man ‚Äú‚Ä¶ sometimes the magic works. Sometimes, it doesn't.‚Äù
BERSERK is surprisingly tricky to spell!  CHECKPLEASE was fun when the penny dropped.  Loved it when TMINUSZERO materialized out of TM - - -  SZ - - -.

Once again, Robyn Weintraub shows that there are more adjectives to describe a puzzle than ‚Äúeasy‚Äù and ‚Äúhard‚Äù. For me, a very important measure is the number of smiles you experience in a solve. Such as figuring out an answer like BABYGROOT as opposed to torturing out a response to ‚ÄùPepin the Short‚Äôs ex-wife‚Äôs maiden name‚Äù. 
I managed to solve this in a respectable time, but loved every minute of it. Thanks again, Robyn. Hurry back.
Lovely echo of yesterday's ROWS puzzle in today's RHOS.

Robyn is right about this being on the easy side but I found my share of obstacles. The last to fall was TMINUSZERO, and it shouldn‚Äôt have been. I wanted to fill in ARTS and DAME but didn‚Äôt like the TM combination that resulted. Ideally, the TM sequence should have caused a flashback to elementary school, sitting in the gym with all the other students watching the school‚Äôs one small television during the historic Mercury countdowns. There were always delays. You could count on endlessly hearing T MINUS something and holding from Walter Cronkite or Jules Bergman. Unfortunately, the flashback didn‚Äôt occur until after I got into the ACID.
They misspelled "woah" again, I see.

The following is a true story.


Woke up at 3:55am.
Hubby was getting up, per usual.

I leave my phone in the kitchen every night- 
except *last* night.
I happened to have left it on a chair near the bed.

Drifting back to sleepland-
thoughts flitting about...

what day is it...Friday...pretty busy day...ooh a themeless...
...wonder who the constructor is...haven't had
a Weintraubian Friday in ages...hmm...I could even
check on my phone...nah...but...hmmm...what are the odds...

I gotta do it...

No.
Way.

C'MON.

Oh yes, there are the big things in a RW puzzle, those fabulous long answers and the playground-in-a-box wordplay that excite the heart before filling in the first square.

But they can mask the little fabulous things, like:
‚Ä¢	Beautiful short answers, such as PLEBE, TOUCH ON, ADEPT, SHEEN.
‚Ä¢	Highly scrubbed grid.  Look at this completed grid!  As I gaze over the answers, I get zen and calm.
‚Ä¢	Zing.  Answers we‚Äôve never seen before in a Times puzzle, such as ALL STAR CAST, REMAIN CALM, SOUTH BEACH, GOES BERZERK.
‚Ä¢	The bar Robyn sets for herself.  Almost not submitting this puzzle because BALLASTS seemed weak to her!
‚Ä¢	Amazing grid design talent.  Robyn did 35 NYT Fridays before this ‚Äì so many designs to choose from ‚Äì and yet debuted a new Times grid design for this puzzle.

What a pro you are, Robyn, not only an artist, not only a one-of-a-kind, not only down-to-earth relatable, but a stellar technician underneath it all.  Thank you for all this, and for another splendid outing!
Smooth and satifying.  Appropriately the [. . . countdown] anwer the last to fall.  RADIO for [Call ahead . . .] a nostalgic touch.  Many thanks.

Very enjoyable puzzle.

TAR was a gimme that gave me a toehold in the SE corner. I worked for the (Canadian) federal government when Harper was elected PM. Pre-Harper we were in the habit of calling the oil sands of Alberta, "the tar sands". Under Harper that terminology (along with "climate change") became taboo, even though the product extracted from the oil sands is not oil, but bitumen -- the tar lookalike.

Switched to a shorter time, eh?





(Baby Groot* called - they want the grownup version.)
*whatever that is
Outstanding. Nice job, Robyn.

Nice puzzle, satisfying solve. I managed to get most of the longer meaty answers with just a few crossing letters, so it felt like it was going at a swift pace throughout. Lots of fun clues and entries. Had to look up BABY GROOT to confirm - my only interaction with Marvel was the 'Marvel vs Capcom' game on Sega Dreamcast 20+ years ago...
Happy Friday, thanks Robyn!

At the very end I was stuck with TEXTBOT / TRAYS, but the latter didn't make sense for [Looks below the surface?] (I originally had DRAGS for that one, but overrode it when I found ACHY). I thought TEXT BOT made sense, as in software used by scammers to send text messages asking people to "enter" their information.

I just couldn't see the answer until I approached the end of the alphabet:

TEXT BOA? Nope
TEXT BOB? Nope
TEXT BOD? Nope
TEXT BOG? Nope
TEXT BOO? Nope
TEXT BOP? Nope
TEXT BOW? Nope
TEXT BOX? Facepalm

I have never not finished a Friday puzzle by Robyn Weintraub, and have almost never not finished a Friday puzzle, period, in all of my decades of solving. But a Natick almost got me by one letter this time. I know nothing of Marvel comics and was never an Elvis fan. And since I solve on paper, running the alphabet didn't help. In the end, I just threw in the T to get BABYGROOT and STAX, and had to come here to find out I made the right choice. But I don't feel that I really finished the puzzle under my own steam!
For anyone wondering how BABY GROOT made it to the puzzle, here's a clip where the sassy little fella is dancing- https://youtu.be/DfNSBeFliIg?si=Jit2QM2qIcwmh-4r

My first Friday with no help.

Spare RIB, DESSERTMENU, and SCARYSTORIES almost sent me into cracking open some Asti Spumante at 7am but I figured it out. Very fun puzzle. Thank you, creator. Cheers.

I remember learning the word MEWS when I visited as a child the Washington MEWS just north of Washington Square Park in New York City, an absolutely charming little "alley" between Fifth Avenue and University Place, thinking to myself that this might be the closest thing to a perfect place to live in the whole world.

It wasn't until many years later that I learned the origin of the word MEWS as the stables that serviced large mansions, and  were later converted into "rowhouses".
Wicked good‚Äîlots of fun. I was a bit groggy doing this one and couldn‚Äôt get out of own way‚Äîhad a hard time rethinking the direction of some of the clues‚Äîbut came through in the end.
Not going berserk over this puzzle.  Wonderful solving experience today.

I hope everyone took a minute to figure out the picture and caption that accompany today's Wordplay column.
It shows the entry to a corn MAZE (with the faint word "ENTRANCE" above it.

The caption reads, "It‚Äôs easy to get into today‚Äôs crossword. But can you get out?"
As someone who has felt the urge to just bust through the "walls" of those confounding MAZEs, it gave me more than a shiver of anxiety!

"Enter Here!"  Indeed!
Nice work, Sam Corbin!
And nice puzzle, Robyn Weintraub!
NW had me until it didn‚Äôt. SE had me because I had SOUTHmiami until I remembered. Great puzzle.
The clue for BABYGROOT is great.  All around enjoyable Friday!
Fun puzzle and just the right challenge for a Friday morning! Off to work I go!
Seeing BABYGROOT here just made my day.  Off to a great start thanks!
Wonderful puzzle, and I'll also add that this was, for me, the hardest Robyn Weintraub in quite a while! No personal record today, but a good, sturdy Friday puzzle.
The link for subscribers to view the completed puzzle hasn‚Äôt worked all week.
Robyn, I'm not  a speed solver. I do these things purely for pleasure, and this one hit the sweet spot. Thanks for a really good Friday outing.
In my 60 plus years I've always thought the expression was "goes beserk", fortunately 9D saved me.

"Berserk" is such a lovely word! Originally a noun, it comes almost directly from Old Norse; it means someone who entered battle wearing a bear-skin shirt, or no shirt at all (bare-sark; "sark" being an archaic word for "shirt," but used by Robert Burns and William Morris, natch). In other words, a crazy man. I learned the original meaning of the word from Frans Bengtsson's Viking-age historical novel *The Long Ships*, which I read gleefully as a teenager, and recently re-read, with equal glee. This puzzle solved like the themeless, easy yet sparkling, Wednesday puzzles Robyn publishes regularly in the New Yorker (on-line, and no-fee, I think). I've been on a Debussy kick lately. Here's an interesting recording of "the Gal with the Ecru Do"*: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wv8iHEM4g7Q&list=RDwv8iHEM4g7Q&start_radio=1 Quite recommend! *Puella linocapillata

I shoulda known it was a Weintraub. It was "just the right challenge to usher in the weekend." Chewy and fresh fill. 

I went bananas and bonkers before GOing BERSERK.

Could not figure out why LATEX would be an alternative to Mylar, thinking of Mylar in heat-reflective uses. Oh, balloons!

FACE REALITY feels rather ominous these days. Nice that it's over REMAIN CALM.

Clever photo choice, Sam.
I thought this was fair and fun-a perfect Friday crossword puzzle.
Just the right amount of challenge

I've been thinking about how on some puzzles I feel like I have painted myself into a corner.  The solve will go smoothly until I am down to one corner, then I am stuck for an inordinate amount of time.  Typically, I enjoy all puzzles because 97% of the time I am able to complete them without lookups, and completing them is mostly what I come for.  But  if there is any one thing that causes dissatisfaction, if only temporarily, it is the paint-yourself-into-a-corner puzzle. 

For a brief moment, I thought Robin Weintraub's puzzle was going to be one of those because of the NW corner.  It did slow me down a little, but not enough to categorize it as a PYIAC puzzle.  As always, a pleasure to solve one of her puzzles.  Solve time 39% less than average.

Interesting hearing that the NE was the hardest for some solvers; seeing TM was enough to bring back all the Mercury launches, and WEEDKILLER went in with just the W and D. Similarly GHOSTSTORIES and CHECKPLEASE with GHO and CH. I finished down to LON in what felt like short order but spent twice as long in the SW as the whole rest of the puzzle. 

BABYGROOT was a ‚Äúwhat on earth???‚Äù answer, but I trusted all the crosses.
I will confess that my greatest difficulty in this puzzle was spelling ‚Äúberserk‚Äù correctly, plus remembering the name of a character who can only say one word‚Äîits own name.
This puzzle was just the right challenge to usher in the weekend!
This was a really well constructed puzzle with really excellent clues! The right amount of challenge to usher in the weekend. Thank you!
Fifty years ago I would have entered, without hesitation, most any crossword answer with a comic book reference.  And I still do pretty well.  Not so with BABYGROOT.  It does have a nice sound though

There were some Seriously Unknown Answers for me, here.  Marvel Comics, brand names, psychedelic drugs, candy.... hoo, boy. 
 DATA BOX?  CHAT BOX?  
Ships all need BALLAST, but it's seldom a plural.
ANTHRACITE and Bitumen--types of coal in 3 letters?!!?  There's not a shoehorn big enough for that space.  
I associate PLEBEs with West Point, not Annapolis; our HS class sent a student to each one--our drum major to the Naval Academy, and another boy I didn't know well to West Point...and wow, he showed up at Christmas with *great* posture!  
I don't even want to know what a BABY GROOT is, but it sounds disgusting.  
Most horses benefit from being SHOD.  (BTW, we need more farriers out there!  It's very important--and not a simple thing.)

Okay, see y'all later.  My plan to join other quilters tomorrow at a meeting of Southern Fiber Artists in a small town 2 hours to the north is cancelled.  The highways are still a frozen mess!

Thank you, Robin, for this lovely Friday! While I did not break my personal best, I definitely took your advice to smile at several of your clues. With current affairs being what they are, I especially enjoyed REMAIN CALM so I don't GO[ES] BERSERK!

I really enjoyed "enter here!," "HDTV component," and "jalape√±o topper." All of those clues felt like they could be part of a cryptic crossword! 

TGIF!! Loved this puzzle Robyn!

Bill! I loved ‚ÄúThe Long Ships‚Äù many years ago and have recently been thinking of re-reading (ahh, my overflowing ‚Äòto-be-reads‚Äô hinder me)! But the longing to revisit an old friend is strong‚Ä¶your post was somewhat of a validation! Thanks.

Yay!  Robyn is back!  Sparkling clues as usual --  and I had quite a bit of trouble in places.  GOT UP before SAT UP for "stopped lying."  PLUS before PERK for "Bonus".   Have no idea what BABY GROOT is nor what/where the STAX is that Elvis was at.

We‚Äôve all been a bit stir crazy the last few days, not being able to get out, though most of us were able to stagger across the fields for the start of the skittles league last night. commentBody: @Marshall Walthew Betting zero when you think you won‚Äôt know the answer is also common, though not common enough. Jeopardy betting is remarkably poor, given how much the contestants train.

@Marshall Walthew -- Especially in the first half, Paolo was SO sharp.  I also like how he doesn't take stabs, that is, if he doesn't know an answer, he stands pat, unlike many contestants.  I also like how remarkably fast he is with the buzzer.

@John

Interesting insight into how James Holzhauer was able to win so much money.

He's a professional gambler.  Of course it's a little different on Jeopardy where a single loss, (wrong answer on a double or final), can end a career.  For a gambler with good money management a single loss is no big deal. 

The presence of a third player also complicates the mathematics of a game-theory approach to betting on the final.

@John

The problem is that guessing that you don‚Äôt know the answer, unless the category is something truly esoteric, such as Lithuanian folk singers of the 19th century, is 100% speculative.  And for the strategy to work all opponents with more than half your total have to get the answer wrong for you to win.   Most contestants good enough to have a lead before final have enough belief in their own store of knowledge to opt to bet enough to have $1 more than two times their closest opponent‚Äôs score, guaranteeing a win if they get the answer right, and leaving chances to win if both get it wrong. Psychologically betting on yourself to win is more satisfying than betting on your opponent to lose.

Here is a short note on the perception of time to keep things moving while I advance through the book.  It reinforces Mann's idea that the level of daily activity and change determines the perception of longer periods.

From William Manchester in A World Lit Only By Fire:  "In the medieval mind there was no awareness of time. ... there are great differences in everyday life between 1791 and 1991, but there were very few between 791 and 991."

Yet the great changes during WWI and its aftermath inspire Mann to regard the events of his novel as happening in the deep past although it was less than 20 years earlier than his telling of the story.

Skittles:
Like bowling - played in a skittle alley. There's one in the Sheep Heid Inn in Edinburgh (a drinking establishment since 1360). Also in other parts of the UK, and rules vary by locality.

All made from wood - 2 wooden lanes, nine big wooden skittles, same shape as in bowling. Sometimes there is one bigger than the others, in the middle, the kingpin. Quite an ancient game.
